channel.title: [Release]Lunasol[/Release]
channel.description:
Link: http://uppit.com/v/X26XEC95 (Correct rotation ints included :))
Well I got bored, so I decided I may as well make the next model in a set I'm making. So here it is:
Wireframe: [img]http://img692.imageshack.us/img692/8883/lunasolwf.png[/img]
Renders: [img]http://img690.imageshack.us/img690/2479/lunasolrt.png[/img] [img]http://img690.imageshack.us/img690/2766/lunasolr4.png[/img] [img]http://img690.imageshack.us/img690/2291/lunasolr3.png[/img] [img]http://img504.imageshack.us/img504/4065/lunasolr2.png[/img] [img]http://img692.imageshack.us/img692/2125/lunasolr1.png[/img]
I'll be working on the next and final one soon, but in the meantime, enjoy :D
EDIT: Alright I figured I may as well explain the concept of this. In each series of swords, they all have seperate forms/releases. In this case, it is the Luna family. It releases from Luna -> LunaSol -> LunaSolNova (Luna's final release). I plan on somehow integrating a evolution type of thing where you complete a quest, go to a certain spot where a seal spawns, and when you pick it up it deletes itself and the previous sword from the inventory, and adding the next one. It shouldn't be too hard, but I don't want to do the coding until I've made 3 families of swords.

item.title: [Release]Lunasol[/Release]
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

Better? It’s really not meant to be thick by any means, its supposed to be as thin as it was. But I suppose it does look better this way.
And btw, I absolutely SUCK at making katana blades, so I made a base blade and just insert and scale it whenever I make a new katana.

Read full topic
